Project  The proposed Tax Administration Reform and Modernization Project is a 
Description  continuation  of  support  from  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  to 
promote economic growth and public governance by improving revenue 
administration. It also provides follow-through support for the 2004 ADB 
project  loan  for  customs  modernization  (2113-KGZ:  Regional  Customs 
Modernization and Infrastructure Development Project). The Project is in 
line with the Government’s objective in its Country Development Strategy of 
introducing modern technology in tax administration, improving operations, 
and  reducing  corruption.  The  Project  will  finance  (i) the  acquisition  of 
equipment and software to develop a central database and management 
information  system  (MIS)  for  the  State  Committee  for  Taxes  and 
Collections (SCTC); (ii) the development of a communication infrastructure 
to link the central database to tax offices; and (iii) the establishment of 
modern central facilities for the Large Taxpayers Unit (LTU), Bishkek tax 
office, taxpayer service center, and SCTC staff development center. 
   
Rationale  The  Kyrgyz  Republic  has  maintained  macroeconomic  stability  and 
achieved steady growth, despite economic and political shocks. During 
2000–2005, real gross domestic product (GDP) growth averaged 3.9% 
and  inflation  remained  modest  at  4.4%.  Notwithstanding  political 
uncertainties  in  2005–2006,  structural  reforms  continued  to  progress. 
Growth in 2006 is estimated at about 3%, with inflation remaining below 
6%. For 2007, GDP growth is projected to be 5.5% and inflation 4.5%.

ii   
  Fiscal  consolidation  has  been  an  important  component  in  the  Kyrgyz 
Republic economy’s good performance, and will be vital in sustaining its 
achievements. The general Government fiscal deficit, which had exceeded 
9% of GDP during 1996–2000, declined to about 5% of GDP during 2001–
2005. Consequently, external public debt fell from 111% of GDP in 2001 to 
70% of GDP in 2006. This fiscal achievement has been due to good 
control of expenditures and modest increases in tax collection. During 
2000–2005,  tax  collection  (excluding  customs  revenues  and  local 
governments) increased from 13.3% of GDP to about 15% of GDP. 
 
However,  the  Kyrgyz  Republic  faces  the  dual  fiscal  challenges  of 
maintaining its prudent fiscal policy to sustain macroeconomic stability and 
economic  growth,  while  providing  for  priority  economic  and  social 
expenditures to help raise per capita GDP above $540 and meet the 
Millennium Development Goals. 
 
Reconciling  these  challenges  will  require  sustained  increases  in  tax 
collection. However, tax administration is beset by inadequate equipment 
and  facilities,  inefficient  practices,  and  inadequate  staff  skills. 
Consequently, tax collection is below potential, operations are error-ridden 
and prone to corruption, and tax administration is not perceived to be 
conducive  to  business  and  private  sector  development.  SCTC  needs 
reform and modernization to install appropriate infrastructure, instill best 
practices  in  tax  administration,  reform  its  business  processes  and 
workflows, upgrade its staff’s skills, and ensure that its operations use 
modern  technology.  These  would  enable  SCTC  to  (i)  increase  its 
efficiency and staff skills, thereby improving its tax collection capacity, 
governance, and transparency; (ii) minimize corruption; and (iii) reduce 
compliance costs. 
   
Impact and  The  proposed  Project  will  help  increase  the  effectiveness  of  tax 
Outcome  administration  to  ensure  sustained  fiscal  consolidation  and 
macroeconomic stability. The outcome of the Project is a modern and 
efficient  SCTC  that  achieves  improvements  in  tax  collection.  The 
accompanying TAs will necessarily have the same impact and outcome, to 
which attainment they will contribute with complementary outputs.

Implementation  The Office of the Government (OG) will be the Executing Agency. SCTC 
Arrangements  will be the Implementing Agency. A project steering committee (PSC), 
headed by a representative from OG, will be established to oversee and 
coordinate  the  implementation  of  the  Project.  The  PSC  will  include 
representatives from relevant Government agencies and private sector 
stakeholders.  A  project  management  office  (PMO),  headed  by  a 
competitively recruited general manager, will be established and function 
under the OG supervision. 
   
Procurement and  All  services,  supplies,  and  equipment  to  be  financed  by  ADB  will  be 
Consulting  procured in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2007, as 
Services  amended from time to time). Goods, equipment, and materials costing 
more than $0.50 million will be procured through international competitive 
bidding, while those valued between $0.10 million and $0.50 million will be 
procured through national competitive bidding.  
 
Civil  works  contracts  estimated  to  cost  more  than  the  equivalent  of 
$1 million will be carried out using international competitive bidding, while 
national competitive bidding will be used for those valued at less than $1 
million.  
   
  In accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines, foreign contractors 
may participate in bidding for national competitive contracts. 
 
All consultants will be recruited on an individual basis in accordance with 
ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time 
to time), and ADB’s procedures for recruiting individual consultants. 
   
Project Benefits  The proposed Project will promote economic growth by providing the fiscal 
and Beneficiaries  space (i.e., increased tax revenues) to maintain macroeconomic stability, 
while providing for priority economic and social expenditures. The direct 
and quantifiable financial benefits from the Project are improvements in 
tax revenues due to more efficient collection. The Project will lead to an 
estimated increase in tax revenues equivalent to 0.1% of GDP in 2012 
(compared with the “without project” scenario). This will rise to 0.5% of 
GDP by 2015 and remain constant thereafter. On this basis, the financial 
internal rate of return (FIRR) of the Project is estimated to be 34%.

iv   
  However, this is probably a conservative estimate of the financial benefits 
for two reasons. First, improved tax collection helps foster faster economic 
growth  by  contributing  to  macroeconomic  stability.  Second,  taxpayers 
(individuals and businesses) will benefit from SCTC procedures that are 
more efficient, which will reduce their compliance costs and facilitate their 
business operations; and from improved governance, which will reduce 
the costs of corruption. These two mechanisms would expand the tax 
base,  lead  to  additional  increases  in  tax  revenues,  and  spur  growth. 
Hence, the estimated FIRRs for the Project are lower bounds. 
 
By  their  nature,  these  two  additional  benefits  cannot  be  quantified 
reasonably.  Additional  benefits  that  are  difficult  to  quantify  arise  from 
improvements  in  social  welfare  when  the  increased  tax  revenues  are 
channeled to social and economic expenditures that assist the poorer 
segments of Kyrgyz Republic society. 
   
Risks and  The proposed Project does not have any unusual technical risks. Risks 
Assumptions  during project implementation arise mainly from (i) potential delays due to 
SCTC’s  lack  of  experience  with  ADB  requirements  and  procedures, 
(ii) potential difficulties in coordinating SCTC’s central database with the 
infrastructure of other agencies, and (iii) potential difficulties of SCTC staff 
in adjusting to the new procedures and facilities. These risks are mitigated 
by steps taken during the project preparatory technical assistance (TA), 
ongoing measures adopted by the Government and SCTC, the project and 
TA  design,  and  Government  assurances.  Key  SCTC  staff  received 
intensive orientation in ADB procedures during the project preparatory TA. 
During project implementation, internationally experienced consultants will 
provide support and training to the PMO and SCTC to ensure equipment 
and works comply with the design requirements and ADB procedures. As 
a  complement  to  the  overall  Project,  institutional  strengthening  and 
change management have been incorporated to facilitate the adjustment 
of SCTC staff to the new framework. 
 
Risks  could  also  include  inadequate  budget  for  operations  and 
maintenance,  and  difficulties  in  recruiting  and  retaining  competent 
information and communication technology (ICT) personnel. However, the 
Government has provided assurances that adequate counterpart funds will 
be  provided  during  and  after  project  implementation  to  ensure 
sustainability. Furthermore, the reform action plan that SCTC developed 
with  assistance  from  the  International  Monetary  Fund  calls  for  the 
introduction of a merit-based pay system. The significant financial returns 
envisaged with the successful implementation of the Project, which would 
enable SCTC to continually upgrade its operations and staffing, would 
mitigate both of these risks.

v
  Other risks include political shocks that could reduce the continuity of 
policy, as well as political pressures that could hinder the Project’s reform 
and  modernization  goals.  These  risks  are  mitigated  by  the  Kyrgyz 
Republic’s  continuing  commitment  to  pursuing  macroeconomic  stability 
and structural reforms under the Poverty Reduction and Growth Facility 
program, as well as development partners’ close attention to the policy 
environment. Passage of the new Tax Code will also help establish a 
favorable environment for tax administration. 
   
Technical  Two accompanying TA grants will be provided to ensure effective project 
Assistance  implementation,  build  capacity,  and  enhance  sustainability.  The  TA 
consultants will work closely with the implementing agency, PMO, relevant 
agencies and institutions, private sector stakeholders, and ADB staff. The 
team leader/international tax administration reform specialist for the first 
TA will be the leader of the two TAs. In that capacity, the team leader will 
work closely with the PMO general manager to ensure that the two TAs’ 
activities  dovetail  with  the  implementation  of  the  physical  investment 
component of the Project. 
 
The proposed TA for Institutional Strengthening and Capacity Building for 
Tax Administration Reform is expected to cost the equivalent of $600,000. 
ADB will provide a grant for $500,000 from its TA funding program, while 
the Government will finance the remaining cost equivalent to $100,000. 
The TA will help SCTC (i) build capacity for modern tax administration 
procedures,  (iii) establish  a  goal-setting  and  performance  management 
system, and (iii) establish taxpayer education and services and conduct a 
public awareness campaign. The TA will finance the services of a team 
leader/international  tax  administration  reform  specialist  (10  person-
months), an international tax administration training specialist (6 person-
months),  a  national  tax  administration  reform  specialist  (10  person-
months), and a national tax administration training specialist (8 person-
months). 
 
  The  proposed  TA  for  Business  Process  Reengineering  and  Change 
Management for Tax Administration Modernization is expected to cost the 
equivalent of $600,000. ADB will administer a grant for $500,000 provided 
by the Government of the Republic of Korea. The Government will finance 
the remaining cost of $100,000. The TA will help SCTC (i) develop its 
staff’s skills in ICT and business analytics, (ii) undertake business process 
reengineering  of  key  tax  functions,  and  (iii) implement  a  change 
management program. The TA will finance the services of an international 
tax  administration  ICT  specialist  (10  person-months),  an  international 
change  management  specialist  (6  person-months),  a  national  tax 
administration ICT specialist (10 person-months), and a national change 
management specialist (8 person-months).

I.  THE PROPOSAL  
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed grant 
to the Kyrgyz Republic for the Tax Administration Reform and Modernization Project. The report 
also describes two proposed technical assistance (TA) grants for (i) Institutional Strengthening 
and Capacity Building for Tax Administration Reform, and (ii) Business Process Reengineering 
and Change Management for Tax Administration Modernization. If the Board approves the 
proposed grant, I, acting under the authority delegated to me by the Board, will approve the two 
TAs. 
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
A.  Sector Description and Performance 
2.  The  Kyrgyz  Republic  has  maintained  macroeconomic  stability  and  achieved  steady 
growth. Economic performance has been satisfactory under the Poverty Reduction and Growth 
Facility (PRGF) programs with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) since 2001. During 2000–
2005,  real  gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  growth  averaged  3.9%,  while  average  inflation 
remained modest at 4.4%. More recently, despite political uncertainties in 2005–2006, economic 
stability was maintained and structural reforms progressed. GDP growth in 2006 is estimated at 
about 3%, with inflation at 5.6%. For 2007, growth is projected to be 5.5% and inflation 4.5%. 
 
3.  Exports have risen strongly since the late 1990s. Due mainly to the development of the 
Kumtor gold mine, exports grew annually by about 10.5% during 2000–2005. However, because 
import growth has been faster at 16.5%, the Kyrgyz Republic has incurred persistent trade and 
current account deficits. Foreign direct investment and unrequited flows (chiefly remittances) 
have financed these deficits comfortably. Consequently, international reserves have improved 
steadily, reaching about $817 million (4 months of imports) in 2007. 
 
4.  The  Kyrgyz  Republic’s  development  partners  have  approved  of  the  economy’s 
performance. First, the Paris Club granted debt relief in March 2005, reducing the present value 
of the debt owed to that group of creditors by about 60%. Second, the Kyrgyz Republic reached 
an agreement with IMF on a new 3-year PRGF arrangement in 2005. Third, having established 
a track record of satisfactory macroeconomic performance and structural reforms under IMF 
and World Bank programs, the Kyrgyz Republic qualified in 2006 for debt relief under the 
Heavily Indebted Poor Countries (HIPC) Initiative. The Government, however, has declined to 
participate in the initiative. 
 
5.  By  complementing  the  prudent  monetary  stance,  fiscal  consolidation  has  been  an 
important component in the economy’s strong performance. The general Government fiscal 
deficit, which had exceeded 10% of GDP during 1996–1999, declined to about 5% of GDP 
during 2000–2005. Consequently, external public debt fell from 111% of GDP in 2001 to 70% of 
GDP in 2006. This fiscal achievement has been due to good control of total expenditure and 
modest  increases  in  tax  collection.  During  2000–2006,  tax  collection  (excluding  customs 
revenues and local governments) increased from 13.3% of GDP to almost 15% of GDP. 
 
6.  Nevertheless, the Kyrgyz Republic’s economy continues to face economic risks arising 
from the limited diversification of the economy, political uncertainties, and governance problems. 
Given these risks, a sound fiscal stance will provide an anchor for the economy.

2     
 
7.  Fiscal management, in turn, faces challenges. On one hand, fiscal deficits need to be kept 
low to maintain macroeconomic stability and debt sustainability. For instance, despite the debt 
relief granted by the Paris Club in 2005, debt indicators remain high. Thus, without HIPC relief, the 
ratio of the present value of debt to Government revenue will exceed 200% through 2009, while 
that of the present value of debt to exports will be almost 100% through 2009. On the other hand, 
productive economic and social expenditures need to increase to help raise per capita GDP 
above its current low level of $540, and to support the Kyrgyz Republic’s efforts to meet its 
Millennium Development Goals (MDGs).  
 
8.  Reconciling  these  fiscal  challenges  will  require  a  buoyant  tax  base  and  steady 
improvements in tax collection. Yet, while state tax collection has increased, it remains low 
compared with other countries in the former Soviet Union and, by some estimates, significantly 
below potential. For instance, a 2002 study by the European Union’s Technical Assistance for 
the Commonwealth of Independent States (TACIS) project estimated that the gap between 
potential and actual tax receipts from the value-added tax (VAT), personal income tax, profits 
tax, and excise taxes was about 19.5% of GDP. On the micro level, the weaknesses of the 
Kyrgyz Republic tax administration create opportunities for corruption and barriers to private 
sector development (as demonstrated by highly negative perceptions in business surveys) in 
the form of inefficiencies and compliance costs. Tax policy (e.g., raising land tax rates and fully 
imposing the property tax) could increase tax collection. However, the consensus is that tax 
rates, especially on labor income, are already too high and have contributed to the growth of the 
shadow economy and tax evasion. Accordingly, tax rates on personal income and on profits 
have been cut from 20% to 10% to foster job creation and the legalization of the informal 
economy. These tax cuts, however, will require improvements in tax administration to offset the 
potential revenue losses. 
 
B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
9.  Efficient tax administration is based on the following principles: 
 
(i)  Because no tax administration has sufficient resources to monitor all taxpayers, 
tax authorities need to (a) foster voluntary compliance (i.e., compliance involving 
limited intervention by tax officials); and (b) establish strong large taxpayers units 
(LTU),  because  focusing  on  large  taxpayers  usually  yields  the  highest  net 
benefits.  With  voluntary  compliance,  taxpayers  practice  self-assessment, 
whereby they calculate their liabilities and file their returns. Officials intervene by 
providing  information  and  services.  Self-assessment,  apart  primarily  from 
economizing on scarce resources, helps minimize opportunities for corruption by 
reducing contact between taxpayers and tax personnel. 
 
(ii)  However,  since  delinquent  taxpayers  are  inevitable,  effective  audits  must 
complement voluntary compliance to enable prompt detection. Given the tax 
authorities’  limited  resources,  such  audits  should  be  carefully  targeted  and 
guided  by  risk  assessment  and  statistical  profiling.  Penalties  should  be 
appropriate and transparent. 
 
(iii)  To  effectively  implement  these  principles,  modern  tax  administrations  adopt 
strategic  plans  to  guide  operations.  Strategic  plans  will  involve  (a) business 
process  reengineering—a  comprehensive  review  of  how  to  streamline 
operations,  including  determining  which  processes  to  automate;  and 
(b) functional  organization—to  promote  efficient  use  of  resources  through

3
specialization and eliminating duplication. Based on the strategy, functional units 
then formulate key performance indicators to translate the overall goals into their 
specific tasks and objectives. 
 
(iv)  Information and communication technology (ICT) upgrading, in close conjunction 
with  institutional  reforms  and  business  process  reengineering,  can  greatly 
facilitate  these  reforms.  For  instance,  electronic  filing  promotes  voluntary 
compliance and helps reduce contact, while a central database and effective 
information exchange facilitate audits and prompt detection of delinquency, and 
provide trip wires to deter corrupt practices. 
 
10.  Judged against this framework, the Kyrgyz Republic’s tax administration faces significant 
challenges. An important and highly visible constraint faced by the State Committee for Taxes 
and  Collections  (SCTC,  formerly  the  State  Tax  Inspectorate)  is  its  inadequate  physical 
infrastructure, particularly its lack of ICT. This deficiency hampers SCTC in practically all the 
major tax functions: registration, filing, payments, processing, audits, and arrears management 
(Appendix 1). 
 
(i)  The  main  operating  software,  Kyrgyzstan  Integrated  Tax  Information  System 
(KITIS), is only about 40% functional and is operated in only four locations. Of 
the 64 subnational tax offices, only 16 are equipped with computers, and the 
minimal computer capacity that exists is not used optimally due to inadequate 
staff training in ICT skills. Consequently, most operations are manual and paper-
based,  and  require  multiple  encoding  of  data.  This  environment  makes 
operations prone to inefficiency, errors, data security breaches, and corruption. 
 
(ii)  Only  LTU  and  two  tax  offices  are  electronically  connected  to  SCTC 
headquarters,  and  the  connection  capacities  are  insufficient.  Of  LTU’s  235 
clients, only 165 (mainly large businesses in Bishkek) use LTU’s full range of 
services. For the others, including those outside Bishkek, services are restricted 
to audits due to infrastructure limitations, such as lack of reliable mail service, 
electronic return filing, and network automation support. 
 
(iii)  Information exchange between SCTC and other relevant agencies (so-called 
third party information), which is essential for prompt detection of delinquent 
taxpayers and the conduct of audits, suffers from delays and inaccuracies. This 
is the result of inadequate ICT, as well as the lack of interagency coordination. 
For instance, because exports are VAT-exempt but liable to profit taxes, SCTC 
should access export data to verify exporters’ profits. However, SCTC accesses 
only import data and limits their use to the processing of VAT returns. 
 
(iv)  The  physical  facilities  of  tax  offices  are  generally  inadequate  in  terms  of 
operational efficiency and taxpayer services. For instance, LTU and the Bishkek 
tax office occupy temporary premises at the State Customs Committee (SCC), 
which are hard for taxpayers to access. In addition, their physical layouts are 
inconsistent with smooth workflows. 
 
11.  The SCTC also suffers from inefficient procedures and inadequate staff skills in the 
following areas:

4     
 
(i)  Taxpayer registration. Measures to make it easier for taxpayers to register and 
for SCTC to update its records could include establishment of one-stop shops for 
registrants  and  simplification  of  forms  and  procedures,  as  well  as 
computerization to facilitate recordkeeping. 
 
(ii)  Taxpayer education and services. Information provision is limited to one-time 
dissemination  of  amendments  to  the  Tax  Code  or  newly  issued  rules  and 
regulations. No arrangements are in place to collaborate with the private sector 
to  provide  information  on  a  continuous  basis,  which  is  vital  to  improve 
compliance. 
 
(iii)  Filing. While best practice is to make filing as convenient as possible, taxpayers 
have to file returns at tax offices before proceeding to banks to make their 
payments. These two steps should be combined, and electronic filing should be 
implemented, initially for large taxpayers. 
 
(iv)  Payments. The transfer of payments information from the banks and the State 
Settlement and Savings Company (SSSC), which handles about 70% of tax 
payments,  to  the  Treasury  and  on  to  SCTC  also  needs  to  be  overhauled. 
Currently, payment data are manually encoded, summary forms are physically 
delivered, and data reconciliation generally is done manually and on paper. 
 
(v)  Processing of returns. The numerical review of returns by SCTC staff during 
filing is contrary to the goal of self-assessment and a duplication of efforts. 
Processing should be purely mechanical to use resources efficiently and reduce 
contact between taxpayers and SCTC staff. Reviews should be carried out at the 
audit stage. 
 
(vi)  Audits and arrears management. Detection of arrears is often tardy due to 
inadequate ICT. Meanwhile, the law requires each taxpayer to be audited once a 
year,  which  is  inefficient.  SCTC  should  use  risk-assessment  techniques  and 
third-party information to undertake targeted audits. While ICT can facilitate these 
two procedures, SCTC staff also need training in audit procedures. 
 
12.  For all its shortcomings, the Kyrgyz Republic tax administration has a good foundation 
for reform and modernization, as demonstrated by the following: 
 
(i)  At the highest levels of the Government and SCTC, support for reform and 
modernization  is  strong.  In  January  2006,  a  presidential  decree  on  tax 
administration modernization was issued. In March 2006, the SCTC prepared (in 
close cooperation with IMF) an action plan to streamline its operations, retrench 
redundant personnel, and introduce a merit-based pay system. In October 2006, 
the Government, as part of the PRGF program, committed to eliminate local 
government interference in the appointment of senior management staff of tax 
offices.  In  January 2007,  the  SCTC’s  status  was  upgraded  from  that  of  an 
agency  to  a  ministry  equivalent.  Also  in  January,  the  Government  issued  a 
resolution  adopting  a  tax  administration  reform  strategy  consistent  with  the 
March 2006 action plan. 
 
(ii)  The Tax Code, drafted with substantial technical advice from IMF and the United 
Kingdom’s  Department  for  International  Development  (DFID),  has  been

5
submitted to Parliament and is expected to be approved in 2007 (a structural 
benchmark under the PRGF program). The code (a) simplifies and clarifies tax 
laws1 and  procedures,  (b)  helps  improve  tax  administration,  (c)  encourages 
compliance,  (d)  reduces  excessive  interference  by  tax  authorities  in  private 
business, and (e) curbs evasion and fraud. Several features of the code were 
expressly formulated to support tax administration reform. The code strengthens 
taxpayer protection mechanisms and increases the period between audits. It also 
provides the legal basis for electronic tax transactions (e.g., it allows accounting 
records  and  tax  reports  to  be  prepared  and filed  electronically,  using  digital 
signature  technology),  and  for  the  first  time  explicitly  allows  Government 
agencies  to  exchange  information  to  facilitate  tax  enforcement.  Accordingly, 
SCTC  has  agreed  to  data  exchange  arrangements  with  a  critical  mass  of 
relevant agencies, including the SCC, the Treasury, and the Social Fund. Finally, 
the code provides the legal basis for using probability-based methods in selecting 
taxpayers for audit, which is a prerequisite for the adoption of risk-management 
techniques.  
 
(iii)  A functional organization and an LTU are in place, and SCTC has established an 
internal audit function and a division to combat misconduct and corruption. LTU 
clients operate on a self-assessment principle, and collections now total 60% of 
SCTC collections—up from 40% in 2005. 
 
(iv)  Although  KITIS,  the  existing  software,  needs  to  be  upgraded,  it  provides  a 
suitable  platform  for  the  creation  of  a  central  database  and  management 
information system (MIS), as well as the extension of the database and system to 
the tax offices. In this connection, the ongoing modernization of the SCC (with 
ADB  assistance),  the  Treasury,  and  the  central  bank  (with  World  Bank 
assistance) provides a good opportunity to establish effective data exchange 
among these Government institutions. The World Bank project has links to the 
proposed ADB Project, because banks course tax payment information to the 
Treasury, which then transfers the information to SCTC. 
 
13.  Tax administration reform and modernization can be favorably combined in the Kyrgyz 
Republic. Such an endeavor should be comprehensive and address three areas: (i) physical 
modernization, including the installation of ICT and the upgrading of facilities; (ii) institutional 
strengthening, including capacity building for best practices in tax administration, to enable 
SCTC to improve its procedures and skills independent of ICT adoption; and (iii) business 
process reengineering and change management, involving adapting SCTC’s operations and 
skills to ensure optimal adoption of ICT.

is the key measure. In tax administration, the Government intends to reduce the scope for 
abusive  discretion  of  tax  officials,  simplify  procedures,  and  toughen  enforcement  against 
delinquent taxpayers. Accordingly, the Government will optimize the organizational structure of

D.  Lessons 
16.  The design of the proposed Project and TAs incorporates important lessons derived 
from  decades  of  international  experience  in  tax  administration  reform  and  modernization, 
particularly involving tax agencies that have adopted ICT systems. The following lessons are 
drawn  from  relevant  regional  experience  (Russian  Federation,  Ukraine,  and  Bulgaria)  with 
projects supported by World Bank and other development partners: 
 
(i)  Successful  tax  administration  reform  and  modernization  require  more  than 
computerization  and  physical  upgrading;  it  also  entails  complex  institutional 
change, affecting organization and human resource development. 
 
(ii)  The  optimal  approach  is  to  move  staff’s  work  away  from  routine  and  low-
productivity tasks toward more specialized, higher value-added tasks. Training 
must be provided early in the process to engender ownership, facilitate change, 
and ensure that attention is not biased toward physical investment. 
 
(iii)  Sequencing and scaling up should be carefully executed. Piloting of modernization, 
rather than full-scale implementation, will enable early identification and correction 
of problems. Because  of their importance and compact size, LTUs provide a 
natural venue for piloting automation and other restructuring. 
 
(iv)  Improvement should be monitored using a holistic set of indicators, rather than 
just revenue targets. Indicators should be developed to measure quality and 
productivity, service orientation, and sustainability. 
 
(v)  Fostering a culture of compliance among taxpayers is important. This will require 
establishing an effective taxpayer education and taxpayer service program. While 
automation might lead to reduced staffing for low-value tasks, more personnel 
might be needed for the taxpayer outreach functions. The SCTC’s March 2006 
action  plan  calls  for  the  creation  of  partnerships  with  the  private  sector  for 
improved  information  dissemination  (including  the  forthcoming  Tax  Code), 
development of simplified tax forms to ease taxpayers’ compliance burden, and 
continuous and systematic assessments of the information and training needs of 
taxpayers and tax administration personnel.

7
(vi)  According to the World Bank and IMF's HIPC Preliminary Document, an essential 
step in fostering a business-friendly regulatory environment will be the adoption 
and implementation the new Tax Code, along with moving tax administration 
toward risk-based assessment and away from excessively intrusive inspections. 
 
(vii)  Because  benefits  accrue  over  the  medium  to  long  term,  perseverance  and 
institutionalization  of  the  new  operating  framework  will  be  essential.  The  tax 
administration should see clear and direct benefits to ensure sustained ownership.

21.  To ensure achievement of the outcome, the proposed Project and two accompanying

reengineering,  and  change  management,  the  proposed  Project  will  focus  on  the  physical 
modernization of SCTC. The Project has the following outputs: 
 
1.  Central Database and Management Information System 
 
22.  This output involves the acquisition of ICT hardware and software to establish a central 
database and an MIS at SCTC headquarters. Building on and completing the USAID-DFID small-
scale project to repair and upgrade KITIS, the ADB Project will enable KITIS to be migrated from a 
local area network (LAN) to a wide area network (WAN), which is a prerequisite for establishing 
computer links to tax offices. This output will also entail the procurement of data warehousing and 
business analytics systems, development of the capability for electronic filing (to be piloted with 
large taxpayers), and establishment of emergency data recovery systems. To ensure appropriate 
sequencing and scaling-up, this output will focus on LTU and the Bishkek tax office, given their 
proximity to SCTC headquarters and their large share of collection. 
 
2.  Communication Infrastructure for Tax Offices 
 
23.  This output involves the development of the ICT infrastructure to support nationwide roll-
out of KITIS to tax offices. Tax offices will undergo site preparation to enable them to adequately 
house  ICT,  maintain  continuous  links  with  the  central  database,  and  operate  under  an 
application virtualization and WAN environment. This output will also involve the development of 
electronic interfaces with SCC, Treasury, SSSC, Financial Police, and Social Fund. While the 
target is to eventually connect 100% of tax offices, this will be done gradually, in order to ensure 
a smooth transition. 
 
3.  Modern Central Operations 
 
24.  This output involves the establishment of a Special Services Building (SSB) to house the 
central database and the MIS, LTU, the Bishkek tax office, the taxpayer service center, and the 
SCTC staff development center. Installation of these functions in the SSB will ensure effective 
coordination (in particular, LTU’s pilot e-filing program will require close access to the central 
database) and efficient workflows. 
 
C.  Special Features 
25.  The proposed Project has features that draw on lessons learned regarding successful 
tax administration reform and modernization, as well as the SCTC’s specific circumstances: 
 
(i)  The proposed Project addresses the problem that the World Bank highlighted in 
its analysis of the Kyrgyz Republic in its 2006 report on anticorruption progress in 
transition  economies:  that  anticorruption  efforts  have  focused  on  legislative

9
changes with inadequate attention paid to implementation and enforcement.3 The 
proposed Project will enable the Government to adopt a twofold approach to 
reducing corruption in tax administration—while the new Tax Code introduces 
improved legislation, the Project will help ensure its implementation. 
 
(ii)  The proposed Project adopts an innovative approach to improving governance 
and minimizing corruption in tax administration. In contrast to prosecutorial and 
punitive  approaches,  which  generally  produce  only  short-term  results,  the 
Project’s design aims to create built-in controls to minimize opportunities for 
corruption. Automation in general will help reduce contact between taxpayers 
and  SCTC.  Meanwhile,  the  central  database  and  data  exchange  between 
relevant agencies will enhance monitoring and verification of data, as well as 
data accuracy and accessibility. 
 
(iii)  The  proposed  Project  takes  a  comprehensive  approach  to  improving  tax 
administration,  incorporating  revenue  targets  as  well  as  quality  and  service 
indicators.  Furthermore,  the  accompanying  TAs  will  help  SCTC  establish  a 
permanent system for setting goals and managing performance to institutionalize 
a performance orientation among SCTC staff. 
 
(iv)  Institutional  strengthening,  human  resource  development,  and  change 
management are key components of the proposed Project and accompanying 
TAs.  These  efforts  will  ensure  that  SCTC  does  not  rely  unduly  on  physical 
modernization  to  improve  its  performance,  but  also  undertakes  essential 
complementary measures. 
 
(v)  The proposed Project pays close attention to sequencing and scaling up. Efforts 
initially will focus on LTU and the Bishkek tax office as these provide the best 
venues  for  establishing  automation.  Similarly,  e-filing  and  payments  will  be 
piloted in LTU. 
 
(vi)  The proposed Project pays close attention to private sector participation and 
development. Private sector stakeholders will be included on the project steering 
committee (PSC). Key activities and performance indicators include those that 
will spur SCTC staff to improve service to taxpayers, such as the establishment 
of  taxpayer  education  and  services,  which  SCTC  envisages  under  its 
March 2006 reform action plan. Finally, consistent with the World Bank and IMF 
HIPC recommendations, the Project will reduce compliance costs (including the 
costs  of  corruption)  through  the  adoption  of  risk-based  assessment  and  the 
reduction of intrusive inspections, thereby improving the business environment. 
 
(vii)  The impetus for reform and modernization in the Kyrgyz Republic is coming from 
the highest levels of Government and motivated SCTC staff. As the benefits of 
reform  and  modernization  materialize  and  the  reforms  become  entrenched, 
additional agents and advocates for change arise, including the private sector 
(which benefits from reduced compliance costs) and SCTC staff (as the new 
operations and professionalism set in).

V.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 
A.  Project Benefits 
49.  The Project’s main benefit is higher tax revenues, which will help the Kyrgyz Republic 
sustain macroeconomic stability and economic growth, with the potential to expand the tax base 
and tax collections further. By their nature, therefore, these direct and indirect benefits are 
expected  to  accrue  to  the  general  society  and  economy,  rather  than  to  easily  identifiable 
sectors. Nevertheless, at least two identifiable sectors can be expected to benefit from tax 
administration  reform  and  modernization.  First,  taxpayers  (individuals  and  businesses)  will 
benefit from (i) more efficient SCTC procedures, which will reduce their compliance costs and 
facilitate their business operations; and (ii) improved governance, which will reduce the costs of 
corruption. Second, to the extent that the increased tax revenues are channeled to social and 
economic expenditures that directly benefit the poorer segments of society, tax administration 
reform and modernization will lead to further increases in overall social welfare. 
 
B.  Financial Analysis 
50.  The financial analysis of the Project was carried out by comparing the “with project” and 
“without project” scenarios. The summary financial analysis is in Appendix 11. The primary 
quantifiable financial benefit from the Project is higher tax revenues. With the Project, tax 
collections are estimated to increase by 0.1% of GDP in 2012, rising progressively to 0.5% of 
GDP by 2015 and staying constant thereafter. On these bases, the financial internal rate of 
return (FIRR) of the Project is estimated to be about 34%.

17
51.  Sensitivity analyses indicate that lowering the projected increases in tax collection to 
0.2% of GDP by 2013 and holding it constant thereafter would reduce the FIRR to 17%. 
Doubling maintenance costs would reduce the FIRR to 29%. These FIRRs, however, would still 
be comfortably above the threshold of 12%. A combination of the two adverse scenarios would 
reduce the FIRR to 13%, still above the threshold. 
 
52.  The FIRRs calculated for the Project are likely to be conservative. Revenue increases 
could be even higher due to spillovers and hard-to-quantify effects. For instance, by enhancing 
macroeconomic stability, improved tax collection contributes to faster economic growth. This,  in 
turn, would expand the tax base further. Improved governance and minimized corruption in tax 
administration would also help to accelerate growth. These two mechanisms would increase tax 
revenues, although the magnitude would be difficult to quantify. Similarly, to the extent that the 
increases  in  tax  collections  are  channeled  to  expenditures  that  benefit  the  poorer 
socioeconomic segments of the Kyrgyz Republic, social welfare benefits would result—again 
difficult to quantify. 
 
53.  The  proposed  Project  is  financially  sustainable.  The  Government  and  SCTC  are 
committed to providing sufficient financing for the operations and maintenance of the equipment 
and  other  facilities.  The  significant  financial  benefits  from  the  Project  also  help  ensure 
sustainability. 
 
C.  Social and Poverty Impact 
54.  The proposed Project will contribute directly and indirectly to the Kyrgyz Republic’s 
efforts  to  achieve  sustained  growth  and  poverty  reduction.  Directly,  the  increases  in  tax 
revenues will help foster continued macroeconomic stability, which is an essential condition for 
economic  growth,  as  well  as  provide  the  fiscal  space  for  priority  social  and  economic 
expenditure that will enable the Kyrgyz Republic to achieve its MDGs. Indirectly, the improved 
governance brought about by minimized corruption and reduced compliance costs, increased 
consistency and fairness of treatment for taxpayers, and greater transparency and integrity can 
also be expected to support growth, job creation, and poverty reduction. The summary poverty 
reduction and social strategy is in Appendix 12. 
 
D.  Environmental Impact 
55.  The proposed Project has been classified as environmental category C based on site 
visits  and  assessment  under  the  project  preparatory  TA.  The  SSB  will  be  constructed  on 
suitable existing vacant real estate owned by SCTC. Thus, no land acquisition or resettlement will 
be required for the construction of the SSB. Site visits were made to the regional tax offices to 
examine the civil works requirements for the installation of ICT equipment. All construction, 
rehabilitation, and installation activities will be carried out within the premises of existing SCTC 
properties, including the site of the SSB. During construction work, some minor noise and dust 
pollution will occur. The civil works contracts will include mitigating measures to minimize such 
pollution.  Therefore,  the  Project’s  environmental  impact  is  minimal  and  can  be  kept  at 
acceptable levels. 
 
E.  Project Risks 
56.  The  proposed  Project  does  not  have  any  unusual  technical  risks.  Risks  during 
implementation arise mainly from (i) potential delays due to SCTC’s lack of experience with 
ADB requirements, (ii) potential difficulties in coordinating SCTC’s central database with the

18    
 
infrastructure of other agencies, and (iii) potential difficulties of SCTC staff in adjusting to the 
new procedures and facilities. These risks are mitigated by steps taken during the project 
preparatory TA, ongoing measures adopted by OG and SCTC, the design of the Project and 
TAs, and Government assurances. Specific steps to address these risks include the following: 
(i) key  SCTC  staff  received  intensive  orientations  in  ADB  procedures  during  the  project 
preparatory TA; (ii) internationally experienced consultants will provide support and training to 
PMO and SCTC during implementation to ensure the equipment and works comply with the 
design requirements and quality standards; (iii) SCTC has reached an agreement with relevant 
agencies  for  effective  data  exchange;  and  (iv) institutional  strengthening  and  change 
management have been incorporated as essential components of the overall Project to facilitate 
the adjustment of SCTC staff to the new framework. 
 
57.  Risks  could  also  include  inadequate  funding  for  operations  and  maintenance,  and 
difficulties in recruiting and retaining competent ICT personnel. The former is mitigated by 
assurances from OG and MOF that adequate counterpart funds will be provided during and 
after  implementation  to  ensure  sustainability.  SCTC’s  plan,  under  its  reform  strategy,  to 
introduce a merit-based pay system mitigates the latter. Significant potential increases in tax 
collection with the successful implementation of the Project also mitigate both risks. These 
revenues would enable SCTC to continually upgrade its operations and staffing. 
 
58.  Broader risks arise on the political front. Political shocks could disrupt the continuity of 
policy makers, while political pressures—including from vested interests opposed to efficient tax 
administration—could hinder the Project’s reform and modernization goals. These risks are 
mitigated by the Kyrgyz Republic’s continuing commitment to pursuing macroeconomic stability 
and  structural  reforms  under  the  PRGF  program,  as  well  as  development  partners’  close 
attention to the policy environment. OG’s assumption of the role of Executing Agency is a strong 
indication of the Government’s support for the Project. Passage of the new Tax Code will also 
help establish a favorable environment for tax administration.

10.  SCTC’s  weak  level  of  automation  is  an  important  and  highly  visible  constraint  to 
increasing administrative efficiency. Nevertheless, reforming and modernizing tax administration 
will require more than computerization. Several non-ICT reforms will also need to be adopted to

11.  ICT. SCTC’s ICT infrastructure consists of the tax administration software adopted in 1994 
called NALOG (“tax” in Russian), which is built around the concept of taxpayer ledgers (or 
personal cards) that record all of the taxpayer’s tax activities. It has been superseded by more 
robust software, Kyrgyzstan Integrated Tax Information System (KITIS). However, only the 16 
biggest tax offices use either NALOG or KITIS. In addition, the database of excise stamps and 
labels is accessible through wireless application protocol services, while a value-added tax (VAT) 
invoice control system has been introduced to help improve VAT administration. 
 
12.  Due to inadequate automation, almost 50% of SCTC’s workforce is still engaged in the 
inefficient manual processing of tax functions. In many instances, data are encoded twice, 
resulting in delays, errors, and exposure to corrupt practices. The inefficient manual procedures 
are unnecessary in some instances—notification letters are still prepared manually, even though 
automatic generation is feasible. With proper equipment, SCTC staff engaged in low value-
added tasks could be reduced and perhaps redeployed to neglected functions, such as taxpayer 
education and services. 
 
13.  One means of reducing the processing workload of SCTC staff is to outsource the work 
to the banks, especially the State Settlement and Savings Company (SSSC), which handles 
about 70% of tax payments. Effective implementation of this method, however, will require the 
installation of data links between the banks and SCTC, instead of the current method of using 
couriers to transfer paper records. 
 
14.  The following priority ICT investments, therefore, have been identified: (i) revisions to 
KITIS to optimize the structure of the database, facilitate automatic generation of notifications 
and reports, and correct deficiencies; (ii) installation of hardware, systems software, and a 
network  infrastructure  to  enable  a  client-server  and  centralized  processing  environment; 
(iii) development of an electronic platform for taxpayer registration; (iv) development of an ICT 
platform for filing of tax returns through the Internet (initially, only for LTU), and for transferring 
data  seamlessly  between  the  tax  offices  and  the  central  database;  (v) development  of  an 
Internet-based tax payment system that will move payments data electronically between SCTC 
and the Treasury; (vi) rollout of KITIS to all tax offices; (vii) establishment of other electronically 
based services to facilitate voluntary compliance and self-assessment; and (viii) repair and 
rehabilitation of tax offices to insure a proper environment for effective ICT use and efficient 
workflows. 
 
15.  Taxpayer Registration. The pressing need is to make it easier for taxpayers to register, 
and for SCTC to update its records. Specifically, the project to establish one-stop services for 
registrants has not yet started, some taxpayers who are far from SCTC offices find registration 
difficult, forms and procedures need to be simplified (e.g., instead of having taxpayers bring 
cash  register  machines  to  SCTC  offices,  manufacturers  should  be  able  to  certify  to  the 
machines’ compliance), and computerization in SCTC offices needs to be improved to facilitate 
recordkeeping. 
 
16.  Filing. International best practice is to make filing as convenient as possible. Currently, 
however, taxpayers often have to file returns at SCTC offices before proceeding to banks to make 
their payments. SCTC regulations should allow for these two steps to be done in one place. Filing 
can also be facilitated by establishing an electronic filing modality, initially for large taxpayers.

17.  Payments. The SCTC offices need a payments system that is faster, less error-prone, 
less corruption-prone, and less reliant on cash transactions. Currently, payment data have to be 
manually encoded, summary forms have to be delivered physically, and reconciliation often is 
beset by numerical errors, as well as being vulnerable to corrupt practices. Generally, payments 
are made through banks. Each tax office establishes a settlement account with a particular 
bank, although taxpayers are allowed to pay through other banks. After receiving payments 
from taxpayers, the bank sends the payment orders by messenger to the Treasury, which then 
splits the receipts between Republican and Local Government budgets and prepares a roster to 
reflect this. Next, the tax office messenger picks up the roster and the payment orders. Payment 
information is manually encoded into KITIS or NALOG if the district tax office is computerized, 
or manually posted on taxpayers’ personal cards if not. Recorded payments are reconciled daily 
with  data  in  the  banking  and  Treasury  networks.  The  workflows  should  be  revised  and 
computerization adopted to make data transmission faster and less error-prone, and to enable 
banks to transmit information simultaneously to SCTC without involving the Treasury in the 
process.  
 
18.  Processing of Returns. After filing, tax returns are sent for processing, which involves 
reviewing  mathematical  accuracy  of  computations,  generating  the  notification  to  pay,  and 
posting select returns data onto personal cards. In tax offices using the NALOG or those that do 
not have computer systems, the reviews are done manually or using calculators. In offices that 
use KITIS, the system’s built-in algorithm automatically detects discrepancies between the tax 
declaration  and  the  computed  value.  However,  the  system  does  not  show  the  amount 
calculated, requiring tax inspectors to verify the computation manually as well. In addition, KITIS 
has not been modified to accommodate the changes to the tax code, which can lead to the 
algorithm  mistakenly  concluding  that  declarations  are  erroneous  even  though  a  manual 
computation reveals otherwise. The current practice of numerical review of returns by SCTC 
staff during filing is contrary to the principle of self-assessment and a wasteful duplication of 
efforts. Ideally, the processing of returns should be a mechanical procedure that uses resources 
efficiently and reduces contact between taxpayers and SCTC staff. Reviews should be done at 
the audit stage. 
 
19.  Audits and VAT Invoices. Current law requires the auditing of each taxpayer once a 
year, which is a waste of resources. SCTC staff should use risk-assessment techniques and 
third-party  information  (from  State  Customs  Committee,  central  Treasury,  banks,  etc.)  to 
undertake targeted audits. Apart from upgrading ICT, however, SCTC needs to upgrade its 
staff’s capacity to undertake audits by recruiting more and better-trained auditors. The auditing 
and settlement process with delinquent taxpayers should be systematic and transparent, and 
should  incorporate  appropriate  penalties  and  incentives  for  speedy  settlement.  For  VAT 
invoicing, the current system is cumbersome because businesses can obtain invoices only from 
SCTC offices, have to record and monitor all invoices issued, and have to submit returns 
monthly. VAT invoices can be monitored more efficiently using modern audit techniques based 
on risk assessment, which would be applied after returns and input claims have been filed. 
 
20.  Arrears Management. Arrears, after falling to less than Som300 million in 2003, rose to 
Som2.2 billion in 2005—33.2% higher than in 2004. Tax debt is also highly concentrated. Two 
large debtors (state-owned utility companies in the energy sector) account for more than half of 
all taxes owed to SCTC. Due to inadequate ICT, detection of arrears is often tardy. However, 
the interpretation of the provision of Article 47 of the Tax Code regarding the order in which 
payments are applied also requires clarification.

and the connection capacities are insufficient. Of LTU’s 235 clients, only 165 (mainly large 
businesses in Bishkek) use LTU’s full range of services. For the others, including those outside

22.  LTU’s  performance  has  been  generally  satisfactory.  Recently,  it  met  the  target,

SUMMARY FINANCIAL ANALYSIS 
 
A.  Financial Analysis 
 
1.  The proposed Project, like all tax administration projects, has clearly defined financial 
benefits and costs. However, the economic benefits are hard to identify and to quantify. The 
financial benefits are increases in tax revenues. Knowing the project costs, the financial internal 
rate of return (FIRR) can be calculated. From an economic point of view, however, these 
increased revenues are intersectoral transfers and are not relevant in calculating the economic 
internal  rate  of  return  (EIRR).  However,  the  Project  has  also  indirect  benefits,  including 
(i) potentially higher growth resulting from effective use of the increased revenues, (ii) additional 
increase in the tax base from the efficiencies and growth stimuli arising from reduced corruption 
and compliance costs, and (iii) social benefits to the extent that the increased revenues are 
used  for  pro-poor  expenditures.  These  indirect  benefits,  however,  are  extremely  hard  to 
quantify. Hence, the proposed Project is not amenable to straightforward economic benefit-cost 
analysis. The following analysis, therefore, is limited to calculating the FIRR. To the extent that 
the indirect and hard-to-quantify benefits lead to additional tax revenues, the FIRRs calculated 
in this analysis will be lower bounds. 
 
2.  The Project’s financial costs total $12.5 million. Costs for maintenance, replacement, 
and upgrade of equipment are estimated to be $1.85 million per year. All equipment, software, 
and information and communication technology licenses are assumed to be replaced/renewed 
every 4 years, at a cost equal to 100% of the initial cost. 
 
3.  The financial analysis is conducted by comparing the “with Project” and “without Project” 
scenarios. The FIRR is calculated over 25 years. The analysis makes conservative assumptions 
regarding the increases in tax collection arising from the Project. The estimated gains are based 
on  the  consultants’  expert  assessments  of  the  revenue  increases  that  can  be  reasonably 
expected to result from successful implementation of the Project, and in close consultation with 
the State Committee for Taxes and Collections (SCTC) and other stakeholders. Thus, tax 
collections are assumed to increase by only 0.1% of gross domestic product (GDP) in 2010 
(compared with the without project scenario), rising to 0.2% of GDP by 2013 and to 0.5% of 
GDP by 2022, and remaining constant to the end of the analysis period. Based on these 
assumptions, the FIRR of the Project is about 34% (Table A11.1). 
 
B.  Sensitivity Analysis 
 
4.  The Project’s economic viability was also tested by assessing the effects of two key 
shocks (Table A11.2). Scenario 1 assumes that the increase in tax collections amounts to only 
0.2% of GDP in 2013, and that this increase remains constant to 2031. Scenario 2 assumes that 
incremental  maintenance  costs  double  to  $2 million  per  year.  In  each  scenario,  the  FIRR 
remains  comfortably  above  the  threshold  of  12%.  A  third  analysis  was  also  conducted, 
combining the two previous scenarios. In Scenario 3, the EIRR drops to 13%, but is still above 
the threshold.

In  view  of  the  country’s  low  income  and  high  poverty  levels,  achieving  sustainable  growth  is  a  fundamental 
requirement for progress in poverty reduction. In its long-term development framework, the Country Development 
Strategy (CDS), the Kyrgyz Republic takes a comprehensive approach to poverty reduction. The strategy entails 
(i) maintaining high rates of economic growth, (ii) creating a favorable business environment for private sector-led 
growth,  (iii) minimizing  corruption  and  improving  public  governance,  (iv) linking  Government  spending  with 
development programs; and (v) reforming tax and customs systems. 
 
The Government of the Kyrgyz Republic aims to reform the tax system to increase revenue collection, while reducing 
the burden on economic entities and reducing the informal economy. Tax administration reform and modernization can 
help the Kyrgyz Republic achieve the poverty reduction objectives in its CDS by (i) assisting in maintaining the 
macroeconomic stability that is a precondition for sustained growth, and (ii) helping produce the revenues needed for 
expanding social services. A reformed and modernized tax administration will also help spur private sector-led growth. 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis   Targeting Classification: General intervention 
 
The level of absolute poverty peaked at about 60% in 1999 following the Russian economic crisis. Although the 
economy has recovered since then, poverty incidence remains high, with data showing that about 45% of the 
population lives in absolute poverty. About 13% lives in extreme poverty. Income inequality has also worsened, with 
the Gini index rising from 30% in 2000 to 33% in 2004. 
 
A consensus has emerged on the causes and determinants of poverty in the Kyrgyz Republic. The high levels of 
poverty can be traced to the disintegration of the former Soviet Union, which caused severe reductions in production 
due  to  the  disruption  of  trade  links  and  the  loss  of  traditional  markets.  This,  in  turn,  led  to  sharply  higher 
unemployment at a time when a shrinking revenue base reduced the state’s ability to provide social safety nets. 
 
The continuing high levels of poverty are largely due to challenges in reforming state institutions and restructuring the 
economy  and  society  according  to  market  mechanisms.  The  following  specific  issues  have  been  noted: 
(i) employment generation has been difficult; (ii) tapping global markets has been difficult due to the Kyrgyz Republic’s 
landlocked situation, limited resources, and small domestic market; (iii) the state’s capacity to address essential needs 
is limited due to fiscal constraints; and (iv) continuing corruption and inefficiency in state administration inhibit private 
enterprise and legitimate economic activity. 
 
The CDS is the medium-term operational plan for poverty reduction. The overall objective of the CDS is improving the 
living standards of Kyrgyz Republic citizens by fostering sustainable economic growth, promoting full employment, 
achieving steady growth of incomes, and making available a wide spectrum of social services.
